thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Satun (Khlong Che Samat), Trang, Surat Thani, Chumphon.
distribution: In the Old World tropics, from S & E Africa through Asia (type from Malabar) and Malesia to N Australia, Micronesia, and Polynesia.
ecology: Mangrove forests.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Chathaburi; PENINSULAR: Krabi, Phuket, Satun, Surat Thani, Chumphon.
distribution: India (type), Burma, Cambodia, S Vietnam, Malesia.
ecology: Mangrove forests.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
ecology: Evergreen forests. Fruiting April–June.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
SOUTH-EASTERN: Rayong, Trat.
distribution: Malay Peninsula (type from Penang).
ecology: Tropical evergreen forests, 50–1,000 m alt.

species_scientific_name: Casuarina equisetifolia L. ex J.R.Forst. & G.Forst.
thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan, Phetchaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Phuket, Songkhla, Narathiwat.
distribution: India, Burma, Vietnam, throughout Malesia, Java, Australia and Polynesia.
ecology: Along seashores on sandy beaches, from the sea level up to 30 m alt. in Thailand, cultivated up to 1,100–1,300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: January–March.
specific_name: Casuarina equisetifolia L. ex J.R.Forst. & G.Forst.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang).
distribution: Ceylon, throughout Malesia to Melanesia.
ecology: On trunks of old trees in dense evergreen forests at medium altitudes.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Satun (Khao Khieo range).
distribution: Sumatra, Malaya, Borneo, Java (type).
ecology: On moist mountain slopes by streams in evergreen jungle at about 700 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Nong Khai (Khong Kao); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Phuket (Khao Phara), Krabi, Trang (Khao Chong), Satun (Tarutao), Yala (Bannang Sata).
distribution: Burma (Tenasserim), Vietnam, Cambodia, N & W Malesia.
ecology: Epiphytic on trunk of larger trees in open places at low altitudes, rather common.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
NORTH-EASTERN: Khon Kaen (Sorensen, Larsen & Hansen 2205 -C).
NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Evergreen forest; ca 1,100 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Pang Mapha).
distribution: India, Nepal (type), Bangladesh.
ecology: In evergreen forests on black soil over limestone, at 800 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – Kerr s.n. [4.6.1921] -BM).
ecology: Open grassy ground, at 2,000 m alt.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
NORTHERN: Sukhothai; CENTRAL: Ang Thong, Suphan Buri.
distribution: Burma (type), Indochina.
ecology: Along river banks. Flowering: December–March; fruiting: in December

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (DOi Chiang Dao – Smitinand & Andersson 7247 -BKF. This specimen is closely related to Aspidopterys thorelii Dop. It can be distinguished by the hairy calyx-lobes and mcricarps, but the specimen is rather inadequate and complete material is needed.
NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao).
ecology: Dense evergreen forests, clay soil under limestone cliff, 1,100–2,175 m alt.

thailand: All over the country.
distribution: India, S China, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Malay Peninsula (type), Indonesia, the Philippines.
ecology: In moist upper mixed deciduous and evergreen forests, 50–300 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: May–September.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
EASTERN: Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: S China, Vietnam (type).
ecology: In forests to 800 m alt.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Khon Kaen; SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi; CENTRAL: Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Yala.
distribution: China, Taiwan, the Philippines (type from Luzon), Malaysia, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Australia, Pacific Islands.
ecology: In forests, frequently on limestone to 850 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Krung Thep Maha Nakhon (Bangkok); PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Krabi, Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: Burma (type), China, Malaysia, Indonesia. Cultivated elsewhere.
ecology: In evergreen or secondary forests, often on limestone, to 500 m alt. Also frequently cultivated.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand

species_scientific_name: Cymodocea rotundata Ehrenb. & Hempr, ex Asch.
thailand: PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Phuket, Krabi.
distribution: As the genus.
ecology: Marine waters below low water mark so that the plants are exposed only during spring ebbs. The species is found especially in sand spots of coral reefs but occasionally forms large mats on muddy flats. It also can tolerate lower salinities; consequently, it occasionally is found in some estuaries.
specific_name: Cymodocea rotundata Ehrenb. & Hempr, ex Asch.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
e-Flora of Thailand
PENINSULAR: Trang (Bangsak).
ecology: In rocky limestone hill, sea level. Flowering: February; fruiting: February, April.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
distribution: Typical

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao, Samoeng), Tak (Mae Moi); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Thung Salaeng Luang), Loei (Phu Ruea).
distribution: Laos.
ecology: In forests, further details not reported, 500–1,400 m alt. Flowering: December–March.

thailand: Cultivated in plantations, mainly in the South-Eastern and Peninsular. Reported 'wild' (escaped) for; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Pong Nam Ron), Trat (Ko Chang); PENINSULAR: Trang (Ban Nam Phrai), Satun (Kuan Sato, Tapan Lek), Narathiwat (Waeng).
distribution: Originally from Amazonian S America (Brazil – type), presently cultivated world-wide in the tropics.
ecology: Reported wild and common in evergreen forests, probably because plantations have been abandoned, in fact only known from cultivation, once reported from limestone, 0–200 m alt.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: Sumatra (including Bangka), Java (type), Malay Peninsula, Cambodia?, S Vietnam?
ecology: Lowlands, up to ca 800 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Lampang, Phayao, Nan, Mae Hong Son.
distribution: NE India (type) Burma, China (Yunnan), N Vietnam.
ecology: Mountain forests, 450–1,700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Mae Rim); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Bukanun); SOUTH-EASTERN: Trat (Bo Rai).
distribution: India (type), Bangladesh, Burma, China, Laos, Vietnam, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Borneo (Sarawak).
ecology: In thickets and primary forests; soil: alluvial, sand with some clay; 300–1,800 m alt.
wfo_full_name: Sabia limoniacea Wall. ex Hook.f. & Thomson

species_scientific_name: Castanopsis echidnocarpa (Hook.f. & Thomson ex A.DC.) A.DC.
thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan, Lampang, Lamphun; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; EASTERN: Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Satun, Songkhla.
distribution: Bangladesh, Bhutan, India (Khasi – type), Nepal, Burma, China.
ecology: Lower montane rain forests, lower montane rain pine-oak forests, dry evergreen forests, mixed deciduous and dry dipterocarp forests, near streams, 50–1,600 m (most commonly 700–1,200 m). Flowering: April–January (most commonly April–September); fruiting: March–December (most commonly August–October).
specific_name: Castanopsis echidnocarpa (Hook.f. & Thomson ex A.DC.) A.DC.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
PENINSULAR: Ranong, Phangnga (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Nakhon Si Thammarat; Trang (Khao Chong); Satun (Khuan Pho, Khuan Kalong, Klong Tao, Tarutao).
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (Penang – type), Myanmar.
ecology: Common in evergreen forests, up to 600 m alt. Fruiting: July.

species_scientific_name: Ipomoea aculeata var. mollissima (Zoll.) Hallier f. ex Ooststr.
thailand: EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram; CENTRAL: Saraburi.
distribution: Bangladesh, Myanmar, China (Hainan), Vietnam, Indonesia (type, Java), the Philippines, Australia.
ecology: Moist clearings in forests, 350–400 m alt. Flowering: August, October, November.
specific_name: Ipomoea aculeata var. mollissima (Zoll.) Hallier f. ex Ooststr.

species_scientific_name: Ipomoea coptica (L.) Roth ex Roem. & Schult.
thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Maha Sarakham, Khon Kaen; SOUTH-WESTERN: Prachuap Khiri Khan.
distribution: Africa (type in the Linnaean Herbarium, provenance unknown), Sri Lanka, India, Australia.
ecology: In sunny, often salty soils near the seacoast or in inland saline situations, <5 m alt. Flowering: March, November; fruiting: March, September, November.
specific_name: Ipomoea coptica (L.) Roth ex Roem. & Schult.

thailand: NORTHERN: Lampang; NORTH-EASTERN: Nakhon Phanom; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; CENTRAL: Saraburi; SOUTH-EASTERN: Prachin Buri, Chon Buri; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Satun, Songkhla, Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat.
distribution: Sri Lanka, India (type), Bhutan, Burma, S China, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Peninsular Malaysia, Indonesia (Java, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands), the Philippines.
ecology: Mixed deciduous, dry evergreen and evergreen forests, also on limestone and open scrub, at low altitudes.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani (Ko Pha-ngan), Satun, Narathiwat.
distribution: Peninsular and Bornean Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia (Sumatra, Java – type, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, Papua), the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands.
ecology: Evergreen forests, at low altitudes.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Phatthalung.
distribution: From Thailand and Peninsular Malaysia to New Guinea.
ecology: Lowland evergreen forests, including swamp forests and coral limestone, soil over limestone, sea level to 500 m (140 m in Thailand).

species_scientific_name: Clematis sikkimensis (Hook.f. & Thomson) Drumm. ex Burkill
thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Suthep – type of Clematis siamensis ).
distribution: Himalayas, India, Assam (Sikkim – type), Myanmar.
ecology: Climbing on bushes, or at forests edges, 700–2,500 m alt. Flowering: November–March; fruiting: January–March, but seasons sometimes not exactly fixed.
specific_name: Clematis sikkimensis (Hook.f. & Thomson) Drumm. ex Burkill

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao – type).
distribution: Endemic in N Thailand.
ecology: In grassy places or in crevices in limestone rock on open ridges, from 1,800–2,200 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: July–November. Rare plant endemic on Doi Chiang Dao.

thailand: NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (type: Chapman s.n. cult. sub. Hetterscheid H.AM. 589-T, holotype -L); CENTRAL: Saraburi.
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Not recorded.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: Myanmar (type).
ecology: None recorded.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Yala.
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (Selangor, Pahang, Kelatantan, Perak – type, Kedah).
ecology: Mostly on sandy to stony, but also muddy bottoms in rather fast-running streams or rivers. At low water level, specimens emerged on sandbanks have smaller, crumpled, green leaves, while submerged specimens are larger with brownish purple leaves. The plants often occur in large numbers.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Narathiwat.
distribution: S Cambodia and S Vietnam, south and west through Peninsular Malaysia (type) and Sumatra, and east to N Borneo.
ecology: Freshwater intertidal mud at sea level or a little above.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan, Lampang; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei, Sakon Nakhon; EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima, Si Sa Ket; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi, Prachuap Khiri Khan; CENTRAL: Suphan Buri, Sara Buri, Nakhon Nayok; SOUTH-EASTERN: Sa Kaeo, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chanthaburi, Trat; PENINSULAR: Chumphon, Ranong, Surat Thani, Phangnga, Krabi, Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Songkhla, Pattani, Narathiwat.
distribution: India (Nicobar Islands) to W Maluku, SW China to Java.
ecology: Evergreen forests, secondary forests, peat swamp forests, beach forests, occasionally on limestone or granite. 0–700 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi.
distribution: NE India (Meghalaya: Khasia – type), N Myanmar.
ecology: Primary and secondary humid evergreen to seasonal evergreen forests, riverbanks; below 1,000 m alt.

thailand: SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi; PENINSULAR: Phuket.
distribution: India (Assam) SW China, through Myanmar (type), Laos, and south as far as SW Cambodia and east to Japan (Ryukyus).
ecology: Primary and secondary tropical rain forests, bamboo-thickets, riverbanks, swamps, sometimes on limestone; below 1,700 m alt.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai.
distribution: NE India, Bangladesh, Myanmar.
ecology: Seasonally moist lowland forests.
wfo_full_name: Steudnera discolor W.Bull ex T.Moore & Mast.

species_scientific_name: Apoballis mutata (Scort. ex Hook.f.) S.Y.Wong & P.C.Boyce.
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son; Chiang Rai, Tak; SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi; PENINSULAR: Phangnga, Phuket, Krabi, Yala.
distribution: Myanmar, Peninsular Malaysia (type and types of
ecology: Lowland perhumid forests to lower montane forests; sometimes on limestone in wet places; robust forms particularly found in disturbed habitats and along stream banks; to 1,500 m alt.
specific_name: Apoballis mutata (Scort. ex Hook.f.) S.Y.Wong & P.C.Boyce.
wfo_full_name: Apoballis mutata (Scort. ex Hook.f.) S.Y.Wong & P.C.Boyce

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan, Lampang, Tak; NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Ratchaburi.
distribution: Myanmar (type).
ecology: In evergreen forests over granite and limestone, often growing near streams, also reported in rock crevices; 600–1,900 m alt. Flowering: mainly January–May and July.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Lamphun, Phrae, Sukhothai; NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun, Loei, Nong Khai, Sakon Nakhon.
distribution: Myanmar (type), Laos.
ecology: In humid or dry dipterocarp, oak or pine forests over granite, also in grassy forests clearings; 350–1,300 m alt. Flowering: mainly August and September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Nan, Tak; SOUTH WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: Myanmar (type).
ecology: In limestone crevices in full sun or partial shade in evergreen or deciduous forests and on mountain summits; 740–1,800 m alt. Flowering: June–September.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Surat Thani, Phangnga, Phuket (fide Seidenf., Dansk Bot. Ark. 31(3): 137, 1977), Nakhon Si Thammarat, Trang, Satun.
distribution: Peninsular Malaysia (Pulau Langkawi – type).
ecology: On limestone rocks in evergreen forests, mostly at low altitudes. Flowering: mainly July–September.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai (Doi Chiang Dao), Chiang Rai (Doi Tung), Tak; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: Myanmar (type), Yunnan, Vietnam.
ecology: Crevices of limestone cliffs in hill evergreen forests, seasonal evergreen forests and bamboo thickets; 640–1,700 m alt. Flowering: July–August(–October).

thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Ban Huai Pong), Chiang Mai, Nan (Doi Phu Kha), Phitsanulok; SOUTH-WESTERN: Phetchaburi (Kaeng Krachan); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo).
distribution: Myanmar (type), Vietnam.
ecology: Shaded humus-rich ground in seasonal evergreen forests and hill evergreen forests on granite or sandstone bedrock: 700–1,850 m alt. Flowering: October–February (one flowering collection from July).

thailand: NORTHERN: Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Satun (Khao Keo).
distribution: NE India (type), Myanmar, Vietnam, Hainan, Taiwan, Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Borneo, Sulawesi, the Philippines.
ecology: Hill evergreen forests; ca 1,100 m alt. Flowering: February–March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Rai (Khunkorn Falls), Nan (Tham Sakoen), Tak (90 km S of Tak), Phitsanulok (Rom Klao); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chanthaburi (Khao Soi Dao).
distribution: Bhutan, NE India (type), Myanmar, S China, Vietnam.
ecology: Seasonal evergreen forests and hill evergreen forests on limestone or granite bedrock; 650–1,050 m alt. Flowering: recorded in December–January and March.

thailand: NORTHERN: Chiang Mai, Nan (Doi Phu Kha).
distribution: SE Tibet, S China, Myanmar (type).
ecology: Shaded humus-rich ground in hill evergreen forests: 1,500–2,000 m alt. Flowering: August–October.

species_scientific_name: Zeuxine nervosa (Wall. ex Lindl.) Benth. ex C.B.Clarke
thailand: NORTHERN: Nan (Mae Sakhon), Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); NORTH-EASTERN: Phetchabun (Khao Huai Khae); EASTERN: Nakhon Ratchasima (Khao Yai); SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi (Song Thao); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai); SOUTH-EASTERN: Chon Buri (Si Racha), Trat; PENINSULAR: Ranong (Khao Phota Luang Kaeo), Nakhon Si Thammarat (Ban Ko).
distribution: Nepal, Bhutan, NE India (type), Bangladesh, Yunnan, Vietnam, the Philippines, Taiwan, Ryukyus.
ecology: Humus-rich ground in tropical rain forests, hill evergreen forests and seasonal evergreen forests; 20–1,400 m alt. Flowering: September–March (but mainly in January–February).
specific_name: Zeuxine nervosa (Wall. ex Lindl.) Benth. ex C.B.Clarke
wfo_full_name: Zeuxine nervosa (Wall. ex Lindl.) Benth. ex Trimen

species_scientific_name: Zeuxine flava (Wall. ex Lindl.) Benth. ex Hook.f.
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Ban Na Pa Pack), Chiang Mai, Nan (Hui Sala), Tak, Phitsanulok (Thung Salaeng Luang); NORTH-EASTERN: Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Uthai Thani (Huai Kha Kaeng), Kanchanaburi (Sangkhla Buri), Prachuap Khiri Khan.
distribution: W Himalaya, Nepal (type), Bhutan, NE India, Myanmar, Yunnan, Vietnam.
ecology: Seasonal evergreen forests, hill evergreen forests and in the transition zone to mixed deciduous forests on granite, sandstone or limestone bedrock; 200–1,650 m alt. Flowering: February–March.
specific_name: Zeuxine flava (Wall. ex Lindl.) Benth. ex Hook.f.

thailand: e-Flora of Thailand
NORTH-EASTERN: Loei (Phu Kradueng, Wang Saphung); CENTRAL: Nakhon Nayok (Khao Yai).
distribution: Indochina, China.
ecology: In primary seasonal evergreen forests, along streams, found over sandstone, 800–1,250 m alt. Flowering: January, March–May; fruiting: October, November. The flowers are scented.

thailand: PENINSULAR: Nakhon Si Thammarat (Khao Luang).
distribution: Endemic.
ecology: Wet evergreen forests, ca 750 m alt.

species_scientific_name: Abelmoschus manihot (L.) Medik. var. pungens (Roxb.) Hochr.
thailand: NORTHERN: Mae Hong Son (Khun Yuam, Mae Sariang), Chiang Mai (Chiang Dao, Mae Chaem), Chiang Rai, Tak (Mae Ramat); NORTH-EASTERN: Sakon Nakhon, Loei; SOUTH-WESTERN: Kanchanaburi.
distribution: India to S China, Malesia.
ecology: Cultivated, sometimes escaping from cultivation, often found in wet sandy soil, edges of mixed deciduous forests, limestone, roadsides, 400–1,500 m alt. Flowering and fruiting: September–December.
specific_name: Abelmoschus manihot (L.) Medik. var. pungens (Roxb.) Hochr.
